description.narrative: Municipal Economic and Environmental Governance (MEG) Project overall goal is to support democratic local governance and improve quality of public services, specifically in the economic and environmental sectors.

participating-org.narrative: SWISS AGENCY FOR DEVELOPMENT AND COOPERATION - SDC

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
Project Main Phase indicators: 1. # of partner LGs where the LG council, the mayor and the administration jointly apply operational and accountable municipal performance management systems. 2. % realization of annual implementation plans of local development strategies of partner LGs. 3. # of citizens’ recommendations/suggestions voiced through public consultation process which were considered and addressed annually by LGs and MCs. 4. Increase of % of households in target localities with access to controlled water supply services and/or wastewater services. 5. Level of citizens’ satisfaction (dis. by sex) with services & infrastructure within target localities. 6. Number of vulnerable/socially excluded citizens (dis. by sex) in target localities with access to improved services. 7. Volume of annual private sector investments (in CHF) in target localities as result of direct project interventions 8. Number of water utilities where the water tariff setting procedure enables regular network maintenance and replacements. 9. Number of improved rules and regulations at higher or local government levels addressing regulatory gaps related to local service delivery in environmental and economic sectors, in compliance with the EU relevant standards. 10. Extent to which legislative bodies at local and higher government levels exercise oversight over result-oriented regulatory framework in the environment and economic sectors. 11. Level of capacities of thematic professional networks to advocate for specific measures in environmental and economic sectors. 12. # citizens living in remote / rural areas who have access to safe water supply services as a result of improved and effectively enforced water governance regulatory framework.
Preparatory Phase indicators: 1. Quality of water management in relevant partner municipalities determined through assessment in order to identify weak points and appropriate measures for improvement. 2. Coordination between

comment.narrative:
Project Main Phase baseline: 1. 0 2. 40% 3. 10 on average per LG annually 4. 62% / 29% 5. 35% of citizens within target localities are unsatisfied or very unsatisfied 6. 0 7. 0 8. 0 9. 0 principle regulatory acts 10. Insufficient scrutiny role of the legislative in implementation of sector-specific regulatory frameworks. 11. Very limited 12. 0
Preparatory Phase baseline: - Poor quality of water management and infrastructure in local governments leads to distribution losses of up to 50 %, increasing cost of water. - Insufficient coordination between local governments, water utilities, sectoral ministries at entity and cantonal levels for the sake of better service delivery management capacity and accountability. - Despite positive experiences, including pilot “business-friendly” certification, local governments in Bosnia and Herzegovina still lack sound economic expertise and tools to engage in productive public-private dialogue and increase investment attractiveness of their localities through viable business infrastructure, support to employability and local entrepreneurship.

1. 18 LGs with at least 60% PMS applied 2. At least 70% realization of annual implementation plans of local development strategies of partner LGs. 3. 50 per LG annually , among which at least 40% voiced out by women/of recommendations / suggestions voiced through public consultation process which were considered and addressed annually by LGs and Municipal Councils. 4. 73% / 36%: the increase of % of households in target localities with access to controlled water supply services and/or wastewater services. 5. Less than 25% of citizens within target localities are unsatisfied or very unsatisfied 6. At least 40,000 vulnerable/socially excluded citizens within target localities (out of which at least 50% women) have access to improved services) 7. CHF 900,000 of private sector investments generated as result of direct Project activities 8. 10 water utilities where the water tariff setting procedure enables regular network maintenance and replacements. 9. 3 principle regulatory acts as a result of direct project activities 10. Increased oversight role of the legislative leads to the result-oriented implementation of the newly enforced regulatory framework in environment and economic sectors) 11. Improved capacities manifested through pro-active engagement in advocacy and best practice generation) 12. 10,000 citizens, among whom at least 40% women)

1. Based on the September 2020 evaluation results, Performance Management Systems (PMS) are functional in 16 partner LGs (without Velika Kladuša and Kozarska Dubica) with an average 82% of PMS being applied (which represents an increase of 6 percentage points vs. 2018 results). 2. The results of the independent evidence-based evaluation completed in September 2020 on progress made in 2019, revealed that 16 MEG partner LGs have an average of 76.82% implementation plan rate. 3. Results of the independent evaluation from September 2020 show that in 16 partner LGs, on average, 56 citizens recommendations and suggestions voiced through public consultation processes were considered and addressed by LGs and Municipal Councils. 4. Support delivered to improve billing and accounting systems in Water Utility Companies (WUCs) has resulted in more accurate databases of existing consumers, leading to an increased percentage of households with access to controlled water supply of 77.8% and/or wastewater services at an increase of 39%. 5. The level of dissatisfaction has steadily decreased to 23.57%. 6. The MEG Project’s Grant Schemes for Incentives, LG activities for blind and visually impaired and people with a hearing impairment or deafness, as well as Public Service Agreement (PSA) activities implemented in almost all partner LGs, enabled improved services and job opportunities for vulnerable/socially excluded citizens. 7. The reported amount of private sector investments co-implemented through the first and second cycles of Grant Schemes for local economic development in 16 LGs amounts to 2,582,527 KM (1,591,597 CHF). Furthermore, 933,777 KM (545,944 CHF) of investments were generated through the implementation of processes related to issuing construction permits and support to BDSP’s. 8. PSAs enabled the implementation of water tariff-setting procedures and key principles to be tested, which led to depreciation accounts for investment maintenance of water utility systems to be functionally established in 13 water utilities 9. The Project actively provides thorough TA to the Government of the Una-Sana Canton in the process of drafting the Law on Public-Private Partnership, the Law on Spatial Planning and Construction, and the Law on Tourism. The Law on PPP was adopted at the end of May 2020 and the Law on Tourism in September 2020 by the USC Assembly, thereby contributing to this indicator. 10. The implementation of PSAs that enable setting improved quality standards for the water supply services and scrutiny role of the local legislative body, have led to an increased oversight role of local legislative bodies in the environmental sector. 11. Network of Local Economic Development (LED) Professionals was established in 2017 and five successful thematic sessions have been organized since. The Project will retain its function as the Secretariat, but incrementally transfer responsibility to the Network to ensure its functioning and sustainability. 12. As the result of the adopted PSAs and TA related to the rural water supply systems, as well as concrete infrastructure activities on improvements of citizens living provided direct access to safe water supply to 10,102 citizens.

1. N/A (Aggregated target 2020 - 18 LGs with at least 60% PMS applied) 2. N/A (Aggregated target 2019 - At least 70%) 3. 20 per locality (Aggregated target 2020 - 50 per LG annually, among which at least 40% voiced out by women) 4. 69% of households have access to controlled water supply services and 33 % of households have access to wastewater services within 18 partner local governments (Aggregated target 2020 - 73% / 36%) 5. N/A (Aggregated target 2020 - Less than 25% of citizens within target localities are unsatisfied or very unsatisfied) 6. N/A (Aggregated target 2020 - At least 40,000 vulnerable/socially excluded citizens within target localities (out of which at least 50% women) have access to improved services)) 7. 400.000 CHF (Aggregated target 2020 - CHF 900,000 of private sector investments generated as result of direct Project activities) 8. 5 (Aggregated target 2020 – 10) 9. 1 (Aggregated target 2020 (3 principle regulatory acts as a result of direct project activities) 10. N/A (Aggregated target 2020 - Increased oversight role of the legislative leads to the result-oriented implementation of the newly enforced regulatory framework in environment and economic sectors) 11. N/A (Aggregated target 2020 - Improved capacities manifested through pro-active engagement in advocacy and best practice generation) 12. 3000 (Aggregated target 2020 - 10,000 citizens, among whom at least 40% women)

1. In progress - 16 LGs with 76% PMS applied. Performance management system (PMS) successfully introduced in 16 partner LGs with average 76% of PMS being currently applied. 2. In progress - Evidence-based independent evaluation of 2018 progress made during March 2019 in partner LGs, reveals that MEG partner LGs have an average implementation plans rate of 65.92%. 3. In progress – Result of 156 recommendations received on average per LG annually. 16 partner LGs have an 84,6% average rate of responding to citizens’ recommendations. The independent evaluation showed that on average 156 citizens’ recommendations / suggestions were voiced through the public consultation process. 4. In progress - 77% of households have access to controlled water supply services and 39% of households have access to wastewater services within 18 partner local governments. Implementation of joint infrastructure projects and finalization of ongoing infrastructure projects in partner LGs contributed to total water supply and wastewater services increase 5. In progress - 24%. The Citizens satisfaction surveys (CSS), performed by 17 partner LGs in 2018, disclose that the overall citizen satisfaction with public services and infrastructure has increased, i.e. the dissatisfaction has decreased from the previously reported 27.95% in 2017 to 24% in 2018. 6. In progress - 1770 (792 F, 978 M) Public Service Agreement (PSA) adopted by the municipal assembly in 17 LGs, and officially signed in 16 LGs, enabled establishing unequivocal responsibilities of utilities and LGs. This allowed for the implementation of strategy/program subsidizing policy towards vulnerable / socially excluded citizens. Furthermore, implementation of LGs infrastructure projects will improve quality of services and number of citizens that have access to the improved water supply services. MEG Project’s Grant Schemes for Incentives, LG activities for blind and visually impaired and people with a hearing impairment or deafness, as well as PSA activities implemented in partner LGs, enabled improved services and job opportunities for vulnerable/socially excluded citizens. 7. In progress - MEG project provided extensive support to its partner LGs in designing and implementing incentive measures/grant schemes for active employment measures, the improvement of private sector competitiveness, and activities contributing to the achievement of LGs’ strategic goals. The reported amount of private sector investments co-implemented through first cycle of Grant Schemes for Incentives in 16 LGs amounts to 1,392,796 KM (812,841 CHF), creating 216 new jobs and supporting 124 businesses. Furthermore, 797,990 KM (464,682 CHF) investments was generated through implementation of infrastructure projects and TA related to improvement of construction related permits issuing processes. 8. In progress - 7 PSAs enabled implementation of water tariff-setting procedures and key principles to be tested, enabling depreciation account for investment maintenance of water utility systems to be functionally established in 3 water utilities (Cazin, Teslić, Tešanj, Gradiška, Gradačac, Bosanska Krupa and Gračanica). 9. In progress - Project developed Advocacy Strategy is setting priority legislative reforms, action plan, key partners in advocacy activities, and risk mitigation measures. MEG project largely contributed to drafting of FBiH Law on Incentives for Small Businesses, Law on income Tax and Draft Law on Concessions, via specific TA to the relevant ministries. Project participates in and provides support to the working group tasked with development of FBiH Rulebook on tariff methodology for water supply services. Project provides TA to RS AMC related to possibility for local governments in RS to take over collection of real estate taxes from tax administration which includes possible legislative reforms at the entity level. Project also assists RS AMC in creating its policy and stance when it comes to the draft of a new RS Law on Budget System, which is one of the most important legislative acts for LGs. Project provides thorough TA to Government of Una-Sana Canton in the process of drafting Law on Public-Private Partnership (PPP), Law on Spatial Planning and Construction, and Law on Tourism. Draft Law on PPP was adopted by the USC Government in August 2019, while the official adoption by the USC Assembly (in the first reading) should happen in October 2019. 10. In progress -17 PSAs represent the basis for increased scrutiny role of the legislative body in LGs. PSAs enabled setting improved quality standards for the water supply services and scrutiny role of the local legislative body. With the PSAs implementation that enable setting improved quality standards for the water supply services and scrutiny role of the local legislative body, oversight role of local legislative bodies in environmental sector has been increased. 11. In progress - Network of Local Economic Development (LED) Professionals was established in 2017 and five successful thematic sessions have been coordinated since. The Project will retain its function as the Secretariat, but incrementally transfer responsibility to the Network to ensure its sustainability by 2020. LED is currently having 21 LG members (3 more from original MEG LGs). The Network is actively seeking for other LGs to join in and provide it more leverage and sustenance. The collaboration with Aquasan has finally been intensified and secured through two types of engagement – (i) Aquasan taking part in conference for participants from all utilities in the country, on the topic of MEG project’s achievements, and (ii) engaging Aquasan to provide delivery of two D-LeaP capacity development programs (NRW and Asset Management) to 14 partner WUCs. 12. In progress - As the result of the adopted PSAs and TA related to the rural water supply systems, as well as concrete infrastructure activities on improvements of citizens living in remote areas, Žepče, K. Dubica, Tešanj and Teslić provided direct new access to safe water supply to 3,180 people. The Project will support registering rural systems and designing Decision Support System in 4 pilot LGs, and in parallel work on strengthening local regulations governing the issue of rural water supply systems.

1. 18 LGs with at least 60% PMS applied 2. At least 70% 3. 50 per LG annually, among which at least 40% voiced out by women 4. 73% / 36% 5. Less than 25% of citizens within target localities are unsatisfied or very unsatisfied 6. At least 40,000 vulnerable/socially excluded citizens within target localities (out of which at least 50% women) have access to improved services) 7. CHF 900,000 of private sector investments generated as result of direct Project activities 8. 10 9. 3 principle regulatory acts as a result of direct project activities 10. Increased oversight role of the legislative leads to the result-oriented implementation of the newly enforced regulatory framework in environment and economic sectors) 11. Improved capacities manifested through pro-active engagement in advocacy and best practice generation) 12. 10,000 citizens, among whom at least 40% women)

1. In progress - 16 LGs with 82% PMS applied. Performance management system (PMS) successfully introduced in 16 partner LGs with average 82% of PMS being currently applied.
2. In progress - The preliminary results of the evidence-based independent evaluation completed in September 2020 on progress made in 2019, revealed that 16 MEG partner LGs (without Velika Kladuša and Kozarska Dubica) have an average implementation plan rate of 76.82%.
3. In progress – Preliminary results of the independent evaluation from September 2020 show that in 16 partner LGs, on average, 56 citizens recommendations and suggestions voiced through public consultation processes were considered and addressed by LGs and Municipal Councils in 2019.
4. In progress – 77.8% of households have access to controlled water supply services and 39% of households have access to wastewater services within 18 partner local governments. Implementation of joint infrastructure projects and finalization of ongoing infrastructure projects in partner LGs contributed to total water supply and wastewater services increase
5. In progress - 24%. Annual Citizens Satisfaction Surveys (CSS) depict that the overall citizen satisfaction with public services and infrastructure has increased since the beginning of the implementation of Project activities. The level of dissatisfaction has steadily decreased from the previously reported 27.95% (2017) and 24% (2018) to 22% in the first quarter of 2019. However, four additional LGs performed CSS during 2020 (K. Dubica, Kostajnica, Prnjavor and Bihac) as an alternative to late 2019 surveying, and their results are less favourable - when compared with the results of the other 13 LGs. This resulted in a slight increase in the overall dissatisfaction result, which might be influenced by general uncertainty caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, or it may even be related to the frustration related to migration crisis in Bihac. It is worth noting that the greatest dissatisfaction rates are related to the quality and frequency of local road maintenance. Velika Kladusa did not organize citizen satisfaction survey in 2019 or 2018.
6. In progress – 2,826 (1,323 F, 1,503 M) Public Service Agreement (PSA) adopted by the municipal assembly in 17 LGs, and officially signed in 16 LGs, enabled establishing unequivocal responsibilities of utilities and LGs. This allowed for the implementation of strategy/program subsidizing policy towards vulnerable / socially excluded citizens. Furthermore, implementation of LGs infrastructure projects will improve quality of services and number of citizens that have access to the improved water supply services. blind and visually impaired and people with a hearing impairment or deafness, as well as Public Service Agreement (PSA) activities implemented in almost all partner LGs, enabled improved services and job opportunities for vulnerable/socially excluded citizens. In June 2020, MEG finalized an analysis of the Impact of the pandemic on gender equality in four local self-government units: Gračanica, Gradiška, Prijedor and Tešanj. The findings of the small research study are applicable to all partner LGs, and some of the seven proposed measures have already been taken into consideration by partner LGs
7. In progress - The reported amount of private sector investments co-implemented through the first and second cycles of Grant Schemes for local economic development in 16 LGs amounts to 2,227,515 KM (1,339,369 CHF). Furthermore, 933,777 KM (545,944 CHF) of investments were generated through the implementation of processes related to issuing construction permits and support to BDSP’s. The MEG Project provided extensive support to its partner LGs in designing and implementing incentive measures/grant schemes for active employment measures, improvement of private sector competitiveness, and activities contributing to the achievement of LGs’ strategic goals. This led to creation of 309 new jobs and to support provided to 250 businesses (out of which 48 women-led and 50 start-ups). The further implementation of these mechanisms will directly contribute to the increased number of new jobs, which is expected to be documented in the next period.
8. In progress - PSAs enabled the implementation of water tariff-setting procedures and key principles to be tested, which led to depreciation accounts for investment maintenance of water utility systems to be functionally established in 12 water utilities (Bihać, Bosanska Krupa, Cazin, Doboj, Gračanica, Gradačac, Gradiška, Kalesija, Prijedor, Prnjavor, Tešanj and Teslić).
9. In progress - The Project actively provides thorough TA to the Government of the Una-Sana Canton in the process of drafting the Law on Public-Private Partnership, the Law on Spatial Planning and Construction, and the Law on Tourism. The Law on PPP was adopted at the end of May 2020 by the USC Assembly, thereby contributing to this indicator. The MEG project largely contributed to the drafting of the FBiH Law on Incentives for Small Businesses, Law on income Tax and Draft Law on Concessions, via specific TA to the relevant ministries. The Project also participates in and provides support to the working group tasked with development of FBiH Rulebook on tariff methodology for water supply services. The proposal of this legal act is ready and the FBiH Government is currently about to decide if it is going to be adopted in the form of a Decree. The Project provided TA to the RS AMC related to the possibility for local governments in RS to take over collection of real estate taxes from tax administration, which includes possible legislative reforms at the entity level. The Project also assisted the RS AMC in creating its policy and stance when it comes to the draft of a new RS Law on Budget System, which is one of the most important legislative acts for LGs.
10. In progress -17 PSAs represent the basis for increased scrutiny role of the legislative body in LGs. PSAs enabled setting improved quality standards for the water supply services and scrutiny role of the local legislative body. With the PSAs implementation that enable setting improved quality standards for the water supply services and scrutiny role of the local legislative body, oversight role of local legislative bodies in environmental sector has been increased.
11. In progress - Network of Local Economic Development (LED) Professionals was established in 2017 and five successful thematic sessions have been organized since. The Project will retain its function as the Secretariat, but by end of 2020 incrementally transfer responsibility to the Network to ensure its sustainability. The team has started this transition by engaging an expert to propose the optimal model for the Network’s future functioning and sustainability The LED network is currently comprised of 26 LG members (8 in addition to the 18 MEG partner LGs - Bijeljina, Ključ, Lukavac, Maglaj, Srebrenik, Travnik, Vitez and Živinice). The Network is actively seeking other LGs to join in order to increase its leverage and sustainability. The collaboration with Aquasan has continued through two types of engagement – (i) Aquasan taking part in conference for participants from all utilities in the country, on the topic of MEG project’s achievements, and (ii) engaging Aquasan to provide delivery of two D-LeaP capacity development programs (NRW and Asset Management) to 14 partner WUCs.
12. In progress - As the result of the adopted PSAs and TA related to the rural water supply systems, as well as concrete infrastructure activities on improvements of citizens living in remote areas of Žepče, Kozarska Dubica, Tešanj and Teslić provided direct access to safe water supply to 6,750 citizens.
